description.original_author: University of Oldenburg, Cluster of Excellence Hearing4all
description.other_contributors: Mareike Buhl, Eugen Kludt, Birger Kollmeier, Antje Wulff
description.other_details: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/.

ISO (2006). 16832:2006, Acoustics - loudness scaling by means of categories. International Organization for Standardization, Geneva, Switzerland.
Brand, T., & Hohmann, V. (2002). An adaptive procedure for categorical loudness scaling. The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, 112(4), 1597-1604.
Hellbrück, J., & Moser, L. M. (1986). Psychophysical measurements of inner ear processes with category scaling of loudness. ORL, 48(2), 135-136.

details.purpose: To record the loudness perception assessed by loudness scaling tests.
details.use: Use to record responses to a loudness scaling measurement and/or the corresponding loudness perception curve with or without using hearing aids.
details.misuse: Not to be used to record any other auditory assessment than categorical loudness scaling. Use the specific archetypes for these purposes.

items.items: A psychoacoustic method used to categorise and quantify an individual's perception of sound at various levels of loudness across the dynamic range of hearing.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Identification of the ear(s) to which the test stimulus is being presented.
The test stimuli were presented to the right ear.
The test stimuli were presented to the left ear.
The test stimuli were presented to both ears simultaneously.
The reported loudness category for a given stimulus level.
Frequency of stimulus tested if applicable.
Provide further specification of 'Type of test stimulus', if a frequency is required. For example: frequency of pure tone or center frequency of narrowband noise.
Additional information required to extend the model with local content or to align with other reference models or formalisms.
For example: local information requirements; or additional metadata to align with FHIR.
The environment in which the audiometric test is administered.
This data element is commonly used in industry hearing programs.
Test environment that has been treated acoustically.
Test environment that has not been treated acoustically.
Identification of the stimulus used in the categorical loudness scaling procedure.

If the type of stimulus is broadband, use 'Name of test stimulus' for further specification. If the type of noise is a tone or a narrowband noise, use 'Frequency of test stimulus' for further specification.
The test stimulus is a tone burst.
The test stimulus is a click.
The test stimulus is a frequency modulated tone.
The test stimulus is a pure tone.
The test stimulus is a narrow band noise centred on the specified frequency.
The test stimulus is a pulsed pure tone.
Details of device used to present test stimulus as specified in 'Presentation method'.
For example: type of headphone or speaker.
Details of the hearing device used.
For example: hearing aid or cochlear implant as type of device.
The scaling method includes details on the experimental procedure. For example: verbal descriptions of response categories.
Loudness perception curve fitted to measured data.

It can either be described through sampled data points from the curve (pairs of response category and stimulus level), or the curve equation and corresponding fit parameters (slope values and specific curve samples).
Slope value for lower section of fitted loudness perception curve corresponding to 'Curve equation'.
Use this parameter, if only one slope value is required. For example: in case of a linear curve.
The reported loudness category for a given stimulus level.
The test stimulus is a broad band noise.
The method used to present the test stimulus.
The stimulus is presented via a loudspeaker located at least one metre away from the subject.
The stimulus is presented via insert earphones.
The stimulus is presented via external headphones - either circumaural or supraaural.
Additional narrative about the measurement of categorical loudness scaling not captured in other fields.
For example: if measurement was not completed or maximum level was reached.
Further specification of test stimulus if applicable.
Provides name of test stimulus, if it has an established name or description of natural sound. For example: IFNoise, Icra1 or, for natural sounds, birds.
The test stimulus is a natural/recorded sound.
Data point of fitted loudness perception curve represented by a combination of a given response category and corresponding stimulus level.
These data points can be used to describe the curve through sampled data points or as fit parameters included in the curve equation. For example: response category of 2.5 CU, 25 CU and 50 CU.
The stimulus level for the chosen CU value of fitted loudness perception curve.
The chosen loudness category of the curve sample.
Name of the procedure applied to fit the loudness function to the data.
A literature reference could be included if applicable. For example: "BX" from Oetting et al. 2014 or exponential fit.
Equation for loudness perception curve with explanation of included variables.
Include reference in 'Type of fit' if applicable.
Information about hearing device use during loudness scaling test.
Identification of the side where the hearing device is worn during the test.
Additional information about the hearing device that is not captured in "Hearing device" or "Side of hearing device".
For example: information about hearing device settings.
The hearing device is worn at the left side.
The hearing device is worn at the right side.
For example: specific audiometric booth or a free text description of the room's sound treatment.
Slope value for upper section of fitted loudness perception curve corresponding to 'Curve equation'.
Additional narrative about the loudness perception curve not captured in other fields.
!!to discuss with Heather and Silje!! Note from April: "For the moment keep curve comment, shift to data layer"
Additional issues or factors that may impact loudness scaling tests, not captured in other fields.
For example: medication or noise exposure prior to test.
The stimulus is directly streamed to the sound processor of a hearing device.
Record as True if no result is available.
Reason why no result is available.
Coding with an external terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: patient was not cooperative; patient was not capable; ran out of time; maximum level reached.
